maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves the Nessus Feed information for a given Nessus Session.
Retrieves the Nessus Feed information for a given Nessus Session.
Index number of the session that the command will be executed against.
Nessus Session object to execute command against.
Index number of the session that the command will be executed against.
Nessus Session object to execute command against.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Retrieves the Nessus server feed information from the Nessus session with a index of 0.

command:commandLine.command:commandText: Feed : ProFeed ServerVersion : 5.0.3 WebServerVersion : 4.0.28 MSP : False Expiration : 9/19/2013 4:00:00 AM ServerHost : 192.168.10.3

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves a Nessus Session

Retrieves a Nessus session by index. The command can take a individual index number or a collection of indexes and retrieve the session objects from the variable $global:nessusconn. If no index number is specified it will retrieve all sessions stored in the variable.
Index or collection of indexes for the Nessus session object to retrieve from the $global:nessusconn variable.
Index or collection of indexes for the Nessus session object to retrieve from the $global:nessusconn variable.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a session to one or more Nessus 5.x servers.
Creates a session to one or more Nessus 5.x servers that can later be used either by specifying the index number in the list of sessions or passing a session object directly.

Creates a persistent connection to the specified computer. If you enter multiple computer names, New-NessusSession creates multiple NessusSessions, one for each computer. The default is the local computer. Type the IP address, or a fully qualified domain name of one or more remote computers. To specify the local computer, type the computer name, "localhost". The command must include the Credential parameter. Also, the computer must be configured for HTTPS transport.

Specifies a user account that has permission to perform this action.
Type a user name, such as "User01" or enter a PSCredential object, such as one returned by the Get-Credentiall cmdlet.
When you type a user name, you will be prompted for a password.

Specifies the network port on the remote computer that is used for this connection. To connect to a remote computer,the remote computer must be listening on the port that the connection uses. The default port is 8834.
Do not use the Port parameter unless you must. The port setting in the command applies to all computers or sessions on which the command runs. An alternate port setting might prevent the command from running on all computers.
Use the user certificate store to validate the SSL Certificate used by the Nessus Server, the default is to use the computer certificate store to validate the SSL certificate..

Ignores any validation errors for the SSL certificate used by the Nessus server. Great care should be taken when using this parameter since it will not check the validity of the SSL Certificate exposing the credentials and information to interception. If the parameter is not specified the command will show the certificate information and validations errors, it will ask if you wish to continue before transmiting any credentials.

Creates a persistent connection to the specified computer. If you enter multiple computer names, New-NessusSession creates multiple NessusSessions, one for each computer. The default is the local computer. Type the IP address, or a fully qualified domain name of one or more remote computers. To specify the local computer, type the computer name, "localhost". The command must include the Credential parameter. Also, the computer must be configured for HTTPS transport.

Specifies a user account that has permission to perform this action.
Type a user name, such as "User01" or enter a PSCredential object, such as one returned by the Get-Credentiall cmdlet.
When you type a user name, you will be prompted for a password.

Specifies the network port on the remote computer that is used for this connection. To connect to a remote computer,the remote computer must be listening on the port that the connection uses. The default port is 8834.
Do not use the Port parameter unless you must. The port setting in the command applies to all computers or sessions on which the command runs. An alternate port setting might prevent the command from running on all computers.
Use the user certificate store to validate the SSL Certificate used by the Nessus Server, the default is to use the computer certificate store to validate the SSL certificate..

Ignores any validation errors for the SSL certificate used by the Nessus server. Great care should be taken when using this parameter since it will not check the validity of the SSL Certificate exposing the credentials and information to interception. If the parameter is not specified the command will show the certificate information and validations errors, it will ask if you wish to continue before transmiting any credentials.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Connecting to a Nessus server without verifying the SSL certificate.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creating a new session to a Nessus server whose certificate we do not have a trust relationship with. The certificate information will be shown and we will be asked if we wish to continue.
